text: as the Sun rises over the west bank city
of ramallah raja Shehadeh bison
breakfast to bring on his walk mr.
Shahada is a lawyer who represents
Palestinians in Israeli land ports he is
also the founder of ah hock a human
rights group but his passion is walking
in the nearby hills and it's this that's
provided the subject matter of his new
book Palestinian walks forays into a
vanishing landscape walking in the mud
line wind among the hills sometimes you
don't know where it's safe to go
sometimes you don't know where you could
be shot at if you go you thank God every
time you come back safe the book
recounts six walks Shahada has taken
over the past three decades and it
features a side of the occupied West
Bank that is rarely seen mr. Shahada I
grew up in Ramallah that began to walk
in the surrounding hills after returning
from law school in London when I came
back from my studies in London I had
plenty on my plate I was starting off as
a lawyer I was starting with the luck
and it was a very big challenge also I
was finding the Society's oppressive
somewhat and so and then of course there
was the occupation and and the
occupation also meant and trying to
understand a lot and understand what is
happening understand how to deal with
the changes that are occurring and and
the sense of despair and hopelessness so
I found that going on walks was
extremely important because it was a
time that I left behind everything it
played very important part in my being
able to think through things reflect and
discovered what was around me
the arabic word Sarha means taking
cattle to pasture and the common
colloquial meaning is going to nature
for the walk without an ending in sight
without an objective this is how it
should be in nature you should not be
going purposefully trying to get
somewhere it should just be an
open-ended walk where you have communion
with nature every aspect of our life in
the advantages is full of restraints
certain strengths in space and also the
feeling that time is against you because
as you see these settlements happening
and and the changes that are leading to
the destruction of your future as a
people in in the land there is also a
time restraint from most hilltops
Shahadah can see Israeli settlements one
of the most contentious issues of the
conflict here because of past run-ins
with settlers he now tries to keep a
distance being in nature I could forget
I could I could just open up and so it
was a way of defeating the compression
of the space that was taking place by
the occupation and in that sense a kind
of resistance to the occupation
the idea behind walking is to leave
behind the conflict that affects so much
of life here but the changes to the
landscape can be difficult to ignore and
this road in the valley was the main
artery between Jerusalem and Nablus two
main urban centers as we can see that
there are no no cards on this segment of
the road because it's been locked on the
two sides and all traffic coming to
Ramallah is diverted to go through the
village which is now a ton of busy where
the university is in order to reach
Ramallah through atara where there is a
main checkpoint so it's a big diversion
Crusader castles dot the land all over
Palestine and now they are many of them
are in ruins and you realize that the
Crusaders which ruled this area for many
hundreds of years nothing is left of
them except these piles of stones
essentially and ultimately that's
empires come and empires go and so it is
very important for ones liberation and
health spiritual health to remember how
we are a small dot in this continuum of
time and and the walks help in all of
this
